transcription.text: >> I'm Luja from layer X and University of Tokyo.
Today I will talk about what we want to do in this Eastern Foundation grant.
So let's start with a quick introduction over our team.
layer X is a blockchain startup based on Tokyo.
We have two research projects.
The other one is Zero Chain features zero knowledge blockchain based on substrate.
The customer research is supported by the same foundation and Zero Chain is supported by the university foundation.
So I'm working on the customer project.
So I will talk about what we have done so far in this year and what we want to do from today.
So we started to get involved in customer research from the former replication project.
So we verified very fundamental lemurs and theorem of the CVC Casper including a synchronous safety state transition.
And very recently we finally finished the verification of finality detection rule of CVC Casper.
It is similar to the six confirmation rule in Bitcoin but in CVC Casper it is much more complicated.
So we think it is important to verify that it is actually correct.
And then we eventually started to work on an academic paper of CVC Casper where we tried to systemize the knowledge of the current research of the Casper
and try to fix some mistakes in the white papers which is accepted in small academic conferences.
And these days I am more working on theory side including an analysis about attack on the
and live analysis of Casper.
I will talk about these results tomorrow at 1pm so please join us if you are interested.
So what is our mission of this international foundation grant?
The first mission is to continue to publish academic papers.
I think the current program in the Casper research process is the resources scattered over the internet.
So when you want to run about the Casper you should read white papers, research posts, YouTube videos, medium posts and even Twitter sometimes.
So this results in an illustration that to catch up Casper research is very hard and there is a very very high entry barrier into the research community
especially for a bit separated community like Japan.
And also there is very very little voluntary work by academia.
I mean Casper is like a consensus in the wild for academic people so there are really few people working on Casper for their academic work.
So in my opinion, yes Casper research is ongoing but we need some systemized papers for the checkpoints of the research.
I think the biggest merit of publishing academic papers is simply that we can get more people working on the research.
You know, top conference publication get attention of the professors, PhD students, masters, postdoc.
So they might get interested in Casper and they might want to work on that.
Currently, Casper research is mostly from inside of the research community so there is no academic work on that.
And another merit I think is the peer review system in academia encourages you to write a paper in a super, super understandable way
because in most cases the labors of conferences does not exactly work on the same topic.
So this allows you to write a paper which is understandable without interaction.
This is I think super important for people who are not confident in their English conversations like Japanese communities.
Another mission of us is to be a layer one research hub in Japan.
So the current status of the research community in Japan is a bit, it's not that big and there's only a few quadrants and researchers in Japan.
I think there's two reasons. One reason is in Japan there's no crypto giants like Polkadot, definitive,
is through likely to give money to developers and researchers. As a result, in Japan there's a little opportunity to work as a blockchain researcher through time.
And there's no Eastern 2.0 team in Japan.
Another problem is there's no top conference publication from Japanese universities about the blockchain.
So this does not encourage students to work on the blockchain research.
And when I say this to my friend, everyone say to me that you should organize a hackathon in Japan.
It's kind of true, but I do not think hackathon and the meetup is a complete solution.
So the AIX has organized the blockchain meetup in Tokyo called "Broxen Tokyo" for more than two years every month.
It was great to expand the community, but it does not grow them to the quality researchers because there's no job in Japan as a blockchain researchers.
So yes, we continue to do some hostile meetups, but I think the fundamental solution is to simply hire researchers as through time and to collaborate with universities.
And the chief, Jan, what is the problem to be solved in the public blockchain?
Yeah, it's pretty much the end of the talk. Thanks so much.
